Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the cost of the stimulus per job by stating it as $278,000 when this figure does not appear in the White House report.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as the $278,000 per job figure is not supported by the White House report and is calculated by dividing the stimulus total by the low-end job estimate.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the stimulus did very little to stimulate the economy based on the $278,000 per job figure, without considering other factors or evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the cost per job figure, such as the complexity of measuring the impact of stimulus spending on job creation.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the $278,000 per job figure does not appear in the White House report, implying that it is misleading or inaccurate.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times bias in the provided claim.
